text:
Hi, I think I might be missing something about interpolation in Julia. I have a Vector `y` defined with respect to a time vector `t`. The thing is, `t` is not equi-spaced. I want to interpolate `y` on a regular, equispaced grid. I thought of using Interpolations.jl, but it seems to me that it targets going _from_ a regular grid, _to_ an irregular one, while I want the other way around. In fact, Interpolations.jl does not require the definition of the input array `y` with respect to some given "time" or "coordinate" axis, simply the indices of `y` is enough.

Am I missing something and what I want to do can be done with Interpolations.jl...?

```xs = [x^2 for x = 1:0.2:5]
A = [f(x) for x in xs]

# linear interpolation
interp_linear = LinearInterpolation(xs, A)
interp_linear(1) # exactly log(1)
interp_linear(1.05) # approximately log(1.05)```
